Fewer prosecutions should be brought against police, fire brigade and ambulance staff who commit driving offences while responding to emergencies, according to draft guidance issued by the Crown Prosecution Service on Thursday.

There may also be no public interest in charging individuals whose driving results in members of their family or close friends being killed because they will already have suffered overwhelming grief, the same public consultation suggests.

The decision to review the guidelines follows criticism earlier this year of the CPS by the Police Federation for prosecuting a Hampshire police officer, PC James Holden, who pursued a serial burglar driving a van that ended up crashing into level crossing barriers.

Holden was cleared of dangerous driving and no one was injured in the incident but officers around the country have subsequently been reported to be scared of being prosecuted for answering 999 calls. Many have called for the law to be changed.

Launching the public consultation, the director of public prosecutions, Keir Starmer QC, explained: "The issues that arise for prosecutors when deciding to charge someone with a very serious driving offence – particularly where there has been a fatality – are inevitably difficult and sensitive.

On police, ambulance and fire brigade drivers, the draft guidance advises prosecutors to use discretion in deciding whether or not a prosecution is required in the public interest if an offence is committed while responding to an emergency call.

"It is very unlikely to be appropriate to proceed with a prosecution on public interest grounds if a police officer, ambulance driver or firefighter commits a driving offence while responding to an emergency call unless the driving is dangerous or indicates a high degree of culpability," the new advice proposes. In the existing guidance, the equivalent word is simply "unlikely".

The DPP said: "Those who work in the emergency services need to know that they can respond to an emergency call without fear of prosecution for doing their job.

"This is not a licence for emergency workers to act with immunity from prosecution, but it is important to appreciate that police officers, ambulance drivers and firefighters sometimes need to drive in a manner which would be not be considered acceptable by other drivers."

Senior CPS staff must still be consulted in cases involving fatal accidents.

In April, following Holden's acquittal, the Police Federation contacted the CPS to raise its concerns. At the time, it warned: "The real problem is the law and the lack of protection it offers police pursuit drivers … It seems there is a willingness to hold an officer legally responsible for the danger created by the driver he is pursuing … Does this mean all officers who pursue could be liable for causing or perpetuating that danger?" The CPS consultation is partially a response to those fears.

In so-called "nearest and dearest" cases, the amended guidance indicates it may not be in the public interest to prosecute where a suspect has lost a "loved one" as a result of a fatal collision.

Starmer said: "The decision over whether to prosecute can be extremely challenging; for example where a parent's careless or dangerous driving has led to the loss of their own child, which will inevitably bring with it enormous grief and terrible bereavement.

"This circumstance must, of course, be balanced against the need to ensure the safety of other road users – and if there is evidence to suggest that an individual presents a continuing danger to other road users then the proper course may well be to prosecute on public interest grounds once there is sufficient evidence to do so."

The changed wordings have now been put out to consultation. Responses to the CPS are due by 8 November 2012.

A judge has told two burglars that if they choose to raid a home where the householders legally own a gun they should accept the risk of being shot.

Judge Michael Pert QC made his remarks as he jailed Joshua O'Gorman and Daniel Mansell for four years at Leicester crown court after they were blasted by Andy Ferrie's shotgun while attempting to burgle his farm cottage in Welby, near Melton Mowbray, in the early hours of 2 September.

Rejecting a plea that he take into account the shooting, which injured and allegedly "traumatised" the defendants, the judge said: "That is the chance you take."

O'Gorman, who was shot in the face, and Mansell, who was hit in his right hand, had pleaded guilty to the break-in at an earlier hearing.

Alan Murphy, prosecuting, said they had a string of convictions between them.

The judge said: "I make it plain that, in my judgment, being shot is not mitigation. If you burgle a house in the country where the householder owns a legally held shotgun, that is the chance you take. You cannot come to court and ask for a lighter sentence because of it."

He was responding to a mitigation plea from Andrew Frymann, representing O'Gorman, who said being shot was for his client akin to a "near-death experience" for which he was not prepared.

Responding to the suggestion that O'Gorman was traumatised, Pert said the Ferries' arrest on suspicion of grievous bodily harm could be considered just as disturbing.

"Some might argue that being arrested and locked up for 40 hours is a trauma," he said.

Ferrie, 35, and his wife, Tracey, 43, were held in custody for nearly two days after he called police to tell them he fired his shotgun at the intruders.

Their arrests prompted widespread criticism. The couple were later bailed and told they would not face criminal charges.

Mansell, 33, and O'Gorman, 27, both from Leicester but with no fixed addresses, appeared in the court dock showing physical evidence of the confrontation.

A scar was clearly visible on the right side of O'Gorman's face and Mansell had his arm in a sling.

Opening the case for the crown, Murphy said the Ferries, who were not in court because they are out of the country, went to bed at their isolated farm cottage as normal on the evening of 1 September.

Mr Ferrie shot the burglars after discovering them downstairs and seeing one of them about to reach into a kitchen drawer that held a number of knives.

"As a result of that, Mr Ferrie fired his shotgun. Mr O'Gorman was hit in his face, Mr Mansell in his hand. The burglars fled without actually being able to steal anything."

The court heard that Mr Ferrie immediately called police to tell them what had happened and found himself subsequently arrested.

Police began searching for the intruders and alerted Leicester Royal Infirmary to see if anybody had presented themselves with shotgun injuries, Murphy said.

At around 2am, O'Gorman arrived at the hospital with shotgun pellets in his face and was arrested by officers. Mansell arrived a few hours later, at around 7am, with pellet wounds to his right hand and was also detained by police.

Both were on licence at the time of the offence.

André Villas-Boas's heart probably sank when he learnt about this trip to Cumbria but it turned into a minor triumph for Tottenham Hotspur's head coach.

With a visit to Manchester United looming on Saturday he managed both to rest a raft of key players and to avoid the sort of embarrassing League Cup exit which could have placed his still fledgling regime on the back foot.

Even better, Villas-Boas's understudies did enough to give him a few future selection dilemmas and none more so than Andros Townsend, who capped an eye-catching performance with a fine goal. "He's very good with the ball at his feet," said Villas-Boas's assistant, Steffen Freund, afterwards, adding: "It's nice to see the young players doing so well."

One of the older ones also took his opportunity. Tom Huddlestone's authority, control and incisive interceptions may have got his manager wondering if his lack of pace is the end of the world after all.

Besides this overhaul Villas-Boas also opted for delegation. Dressed down in a tracksuit, he opted to spend much of the first half quietly in the dug-out, leaving most of the technical area arm-waving and finger-pointing to Freund.

If Danny Livesey's clearance off the line from Clint Dempsey denied Freund the chance to punch the air in celebration, Greg Abbott's League One side were showing that they, too, can play a bit.

Abbott's entire squad was assembled for £60,000 but he has recruited cleverly and the attacking combination of Danny Cadamarteri, once of Everton, and Kallum Higginbotham, borrowed from Huddersfield, sporadically stretched Michael Dawson and his defensive colleagues to the limit. On more than one occasion Huddlestone was required to drop back from midfield and make last-ditch interventions.

With Townsend showing glimpses of promise on the right wing Tottenham took such scares in their stride. Yet, even though they moved the ball slickly and smoothly across a pitch which ranks as one of England's finest, there was clear relief among the away contingent when Jan Vertonghen, the visiting left-back for the night, headed Gylfi Sigurdsson's floated delivery beyond Mark Gillespie. Abbott's players had paid the price for Paul Thirlwell's foul on Dempsey and the resulting free-kick which enabled Sigurdsson to show off his dead-ball skills.

Gillespie had been stranded when Vertonghen headed the opener and Carlisle's 20-year-old goalkeeper found himself similarly powerless early in the second half when Townsend's superb low left-foot shot into the bottom corner from just outside the area eluded him.

Abbott responded with a triple substition. It was a big moment for two of the newcomers, Mark Beck and David Symington, a pair fast-tracked from the youth team who earn only £150 a week each.

Creditably Carlisle never gave up but their diligent pressing was ultimately no match for their guests who scored a deserved third when Sigurdsson headed the substitute Kyle Walker's cross past Gillespie to score his first Spurs goal.

The Drudge Report, which I've always considered more mischievous than malicious, gave "Unskewedpolls.com" some link love earlier this week. The site tinkers with the poll results of major firms by re-weighting them according to the national proportions of Democrats to Republicans, as determined by the notoriously GOP-friendly Rassmussen group. Fans of the "unskewed polls" see them as a way of countering what conservative critics consider to be the "undercounting" Republican votes.

I have trouble with figuring how, exactly, the creator of Unskewed polls comes to the cheerful outcomes he does: it seems like the most simplistic kind of magical thinking. The site has led to many mocking "unskewed" assertions and representatives of the firms have expressed a more gentle befuddlement with the project:

"'Why would pollsters want to look inaccurate?,' [director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, Lew ]Miringoff asked rhetorically in a phone interview."

At their heart, Unskewed Polls express a pseudoscientific rationalization for a pre-existing belief: the mathematical equivalent of intelligent design. But the site represents more than just modern conservatism's skepticism about science; it underscores what has become a more animating and alarming concern – conservatives' distrust of democracy as a process.

This is nothing new, of course. Edmund Burke railed with a kind of admirable irascibility against democracy ("A perfect democracy is, therefore, the most shameless thing in the world"). Closer to home, the Anti-Federalists pitched a near-victorious battle in the United States against more direct forms of democracy, which they saw as inevitably victim, as James Madison put it, to "the turbulency and weakness of unruly passions". They pushed successfully for the US constitution to mandate election of senators by state legislatures and not voters – a quaint affectation that was superseded by the 17th amendment in 1913.

There is a growing movement among Republican elected officials to repeal that amendment; among those advocates are five Republican Senate nominees.

In my darker moments, I have some sympathy with the anti-democratic arguments: I wonder if I really want the same populace that made Kim Kardashian famous selecting the brains trust responsible for acts of war. (Granted, Kim Kardashian couldn't have made a worse hash of Iraq than the Bush team did. In fact, she might have gotten out of it sooner.)

However, it is one thing to wonder if the mass electorate can make good decisions and quite another to back-engineer the exclusion of a specific class of voters for the sake of a specific outcome. That, of course, is what voter ID laws do.

But voter ID laws are just a specific, particularly obvious example of a generalized contempt for voters. A better reflection of the mood: Romney's careless dismissal of 47% of America. The comment wasn't just callous and strategically idiotic (Karl Rove, who masterminded the GOP's outreach to "ungettable" voters, must have hurt his head banging it against the wall when he heard); it reflected also the apparently widespread presumption among GOP supporters that democracy is a zero-sum game – and that voters are motivated out of greed.

Scratch a conservative argument for voter ID, or in support of Romney's videoed comments, and you usually get this quote:

"A democracy cannot exist as a permanent form of government. It can only exist until the majority discovers it can vote itself largesse out of the public treasury."

Notwithstanding whatever it is that motivates voting for the candidate proposing the largest tax cuts, conservatives who parrot this quote aren't really sounding the alarm against the end of democracy; they are arguing against democracy, full stop. Rush Limbaugh is fond of this formulation:

"I think that the country could survive four more years of Obama … But I don't believe the country can survive in a country full of people who would re-elect him."

The next step in such a logic chain is to keep those who would re-elect him from voting. We had to burn our freedoms in order to save them, or some such.

Ironically, the "largesse" quote that sounds so delightfully authoritive – it is often attributed to Tocqueville, or, more frequently, Scottish (so no wonder he's grumpy) historian Alexander Tytler – goes no further back than 1951: it was first found in an op-ed in the Daily Oklahoman.

Tytler, in real life, was certainly a curmudgeon about the sustainability of democracy, but the misattributed quote captures all of his pessimism about the process without any of his sympathy for the people who are a part of it. Tytler was suspicious about how much could be achieved in a democracy not because he thought the electorate was greedy, but because the elected officials were even more selfish:

"But those governors once selected, where is the boasted freedom of the people? They must submit to their rule and control, with the same abandonment of their natural liberty, the freedom of their will, and the command of their actions, as if they were under the rule of a monarch."

Tytler grudgingly accepted that democracy, with all its faults, stood the best chance of securing the maximum liberty for the greatest number of people:

"[T]his form of government is the best adapted to produce, though not the most frequent, yet the most striking, examples of virtue in individuals."

You can almost hear him sigh and cue up "The Daily Show" on his DVR.

Republicans' assault on democracy (the voter ID laws, the repeal of the 17th amendment, the creeping disempowerment of women) is probably designed to scare those exact voters they want to disenfranchise as much as it is to legally disenfranchise them. Anti-voter ID activists often say that making someone believe their vote won't count is as effective as actually barring the vote.

Tytler offers some hope on this score. Of patriotism he wrote.

"Like all other affections it operates with the greatest force where it meets with greatest difficulties. It seems to be a virtue which grows from which subsists in its greatest vigor amidst turbulence dangers, but in a state of ease and safety as if wanting its nourishment it languishes and decays."

So, you know, bring it on. It's not the 47% that needs to worry; it's Romney.

The national Republican party appears to be thawing its attitude towards controversial Senate candidate Todd Akin and preparing to raise money for his campaign after a deadline for him to drop out of his race in Missouri passed.

Akin was cut off by the party leadership – including presidential candidate Mitt Romney – in August after saying in an interview that women could not become pregnant in cases of "legitimate rape". The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC), which raises cash for candidates, withdrew $5m worth of advertising support for the Missouri campaign and Romney led calls for Akin to step down. Akin, however, refused to quit.

But now the NRSC has indicated that its principled stand may have been overtaken by realpolitik, saying it will "monitor" Akin's fight against Democratic incumbent Claire McCaskill.

"Todd Akin is a far more preferable candidate than liberal senator Claire McCaskill. As with every Republican Senate candidate, we hope Todd Akin wins in November, and we will continue to monitor this race closely in the days ahead," NRSC executive director Rob Jesmer said in a statement first reported by Talking Points Memo.

A week ago, NRSC chairman John Cornyn was asked by The Hill if the group would back Akin and he replied: "We're done."

The distinct change in tone almost certainly reflects the fact that Akin is now certain to be the Republican candidate in a race that is vital for eventual control of the entire Senate – a prize even more important to the Republicans with Romney falling behind in the White House election.

The shift of the party also likely reflects Akin's relatively healthy position in the opinion polls. Though Akin's comments over rape outraged women's groups and made headline news across the country, he has remained competitive with McCaskill.

Patty Murray, a Washington senator and chair of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, denouned the NRSC's reversal as "absolutely shameful". She said: "I expected more, but sadly, Todd Akin represents the official position of the Republican Party."

Missouri Democrats said they were unsurprised by the shift. Jim Sanders, the state party chair, told Talking Points Memo: "We've always expected these dollars to flow in. So when you heard from the Republican side the outcry that 'we're going to pull away from Todd Akin' we never thought that would be the case."

Akin has become a rallying point for several high-profile conservatives within the national party who laud his social conservative stances on issues like abortion.

Earlier on Wednesday former presidential contender Rick Santorum and Tea Party favourite South Carolina senator Jim DeMint issued a joint statement in support of Akin. "Todd Akin is a principled conservative who is committed to winning and fighting for freedom in the US Senate," the politicians said, praising Akin for his principles on debt reduction and being against Barack Obama's healthcare reforms.

Akin is now likely to receive cash help for his campaign from Super Pacs that support Santorum and DeMint. In a brief statement he thanked the two for supporting him. "I am proud to have two of our country's leading conservatives endorse me today … our country can't afford another six years of the liberal agenda of Claire McCaskill," Akin said.

Another former presidential hopeful, ex-House Speaker Newt Gingrich, has also taken a firm line in defending Akin and helping to pour money into his campaign coffers. On Monday, Gingrich hosted a fundraising lunch for Akin which saw donors coughing up $500 each to attend.

In another sign that the Republican party as a whole is now rallying behind Akin, the state party in Missouri has also now firmly backed him. "We are confident that Todd will defeat McCaskill in November, and the Missouri Republican party will do everything we can to assist in his efforts," the party said in a statement.

However, even if money does once again start to pour into Akin's campaign, he still faces an uphill battle in the cash stakes. According to the Center for Responsive Politics McCaskill had raised $10m more than Akin through the first half of 2012.

But the change in opinion by outside figures does represent a remarkable turnaround for Akin. In the wake of his rape comments, which were made in the context of defending a 'no-exceptions' belief when it came to abortion, his political career was virtually written off. Democrats and Republicans alike queued up to condemn him and ask him to step aside for a new candidate, and he became the punchline to the jokes of late-night comedians.

His determination to stay in the race has now firmly paid off. Missouri's other Senator, Republican Roy Blunt, had once called for Akin to quit but has now promised support. "I'll be working for the Republican ticket in Missouri, and that includes Todd Akin," he said last week.

Preamble: Good evening everybody and welcome to tonight's coverage of a match that won't be featuring anywhere near the top of either club's list of priorities for this season, but which will hopefully be worth watching nonetheless. Considering the weather, the game being televised and the cheapest tickets available to adult home fans that aren't OAPs cost £30 (visiting adult Geordies have had to fork out £45!), we're unlikely to have anything resembling a full house at Old Trafford tonight, but we might get to see some bright new prospects line up for both sides. More seasoned lags such as Darren Fletcher and Wayne Rooney should also feature. The former continues his return from debilitating illness, while the latter is expected to return from a debilitating bloody great hole in the leg.

Angelo Henriquez, Nick Powell, Alex Buttner and Michael Keane are among the whelps who are expected to either start or come on as substitutes for Manchester United at some point tonight. Midfielder Powell and left-back Buttner have already featured in the Premier League against Wigan this season, with both players scoring and the Dutch defender picking up the man of the match fizz. Keane made his only appearance for United in this competition last season and is not to be (but perhaps often is) confused with twin brother Will, who also plays for United. Finally recruited from Universidad de Chile after a bit of an administrative nightmare earlier this month, Henriquez scored 11 goals in 17 appearances for the Chilean side last season.

Newcastle manager Alan Pardew has signalled his intention to select a pretty experienced side this evening, with midfielder Cheikh Tiote and centre-half Fabricio Coloccini likely to return from injury. ""Obviously, as a manager, you are going to protect players for competitions you think are more important to grow as a club and we are trying to grow here," said Pardew ahead of tonight's match, adding: "I know one thing, the team I put out will have to be able to win."

Team news: Wayne Rooney returns from injury to take his place in the Manchester United line-up tonight, while Darren Fletcher is named skipper on his first start for 10 months. He'll lead out a team featuring a back four with just two appearances between them; Marnick Vermijl and Scott Wooton are handed their debuts.

For Newcastle, as expected, Cheick Tiote makes only his second appearance of the season, whilst Fabricio Coloccini returns after a three-match absence.

Random bit of trivia while we wait for the line-ups to appear on the wires, so that I can copy-and-paste rather than type them out: It's been 40 years since Newcastle United won away at Old Trafford.

Man Utd: De Gea, Vermiji, Wootton, Keane, Buttner, Cleverley, Fletcher, Anderson, Rooney, Welbeck, Hernandez.
Subs: Johnstone, Evans, Powell, Lingard, Brady, King, Tunnicliffe.

Newcastle: Elliot, Perch, Williamson, Coloccini, Tavernier,
Obertan, Tiote, Gosling, Marveaux, Vuckic, Shola Ameobi.
Subs: Harper, Anita, Cisse, Amalfitano, Bigirimana, Sammy Ameobi, Ferguson.

Referee: Anthony Taylor (Cheshire)

A pre-match email: "Marneck Vermilj, United's starting right-back, does not even have a Wikipedia page," writes Dan Schulwolf. "Surely this is the sign of a club in crisis."

Alan Pardew speaks: In his pre-match interview, the Newcastle manager says he and his backroom team have noticed that Manchester United's defence "look a bit light on set pieces" and is duly applaiuded by the pundits for showing his hand before the match has started.

Fair dues, he could have not mentioned it, but noticing that your opposition are lining up with four defenders with two appearances between them, then pointing out that it might be a good idea to batter them with Shola Ameobi hardly merits a Manager of the Month award.

Oh ... speaking of Alan Pardew - you may well have seen this already. Presuming he has, I wonder did he feel really disturbed or secretly pleased upon viewing it for the first few times.

Javier Hernandez kneels just to the right of the centre-circle for his pre-match pray: Once he's done, the referee blows the whistle and Newcastle kick off playing from right to left into the Stretford End.

1 min: I thought Darren Fletcher was going to play on the right side of midfield, but he appears to have taken up a position just in front of a back four comprising Vermiji at right-back, Scott Wootton and Michael Keane in the centre and Alex Buttner at left-back. In midfield, we have Fletcher in a withdrawn role behind Cleverley and Anderson, then Rooney, Welbeck and Hernandez up front.

4 min: If United's defensive whelps are nervous tonight, they're hiding it well. Buttner has already had a shot on goal, which fizzed over Rob Elliot's crossbar, while Marnick Vermiji has just sent in a cross from the right that was perfectly placed for Javier Hernandez, who sent a header flashing across the face of goal and wide.

5 min: Newcastle are playing a 4-4-2, with the back four much as you'd expect, Obertan on the right of midfield, Marveaux on the left and Tiote and Gosling in the middle. Vuckic and Ameobi form a two-pronged attack.

7 min: Newcastle win a free-kick on the left flank for a Scott Wootton foul on Haris Vuckic. Marveaux stands over the ball waiting for Newcastle's centre-halves to come up and exert pressure on the Manchester United defence. The delivery to the far post is perfect and Mike Williamson rises highest to head the ball goalwards, only for Fabricio Coloccini to get in his way, handle the ball and concede a free to Manchester United.

9 min: Another free-kick for Newcastle from which nothing comes and Anderson launches a counter-attack. His pass-selection is poor and he plays the ball right to Javier Hernandez on the right flank, where Rooney and Cleverley were galloping forward in a two-on-one against James Perch on the left.

12 min: Another free-kick a long way out for Newcastle and the ball is pumped into the box again. United half-clear, Shola Ameobi picks up the loose ball and attempts to get it in the box, only for Haris Vuckic to be flagged for offside.

13 min: Newcastle get the ball into the box for Shola Ameobi, who knocks it down to Dan Gosling, standing unmarked about 12 yards out. The midfielder takes a swing, but scuffs his shot, passing up a glorious opportunity to open the scoring for Newcastle.

15 min: Splendid save from Newcastle goalkeeper Rob Elliot, who tips a rasping Anderson drive around the pass when the Brazilian looked certain to score after picking up the ball in midfield, passing to Rooney and picking up the return and holding off Coloccini for long enough to unleash his shot.

18 min: Prior to the Anderson goal chance, Wayne Rooney appealed for a penalty after going to ground as James Tavernier tried to get goal side of the striker as he attempted to pick up a diagonal pass from Anderson. Should it have been a penalty? I've seen it once in real time and once in slow motion and still can't say for sure. Who'd be a referee?

19 min: "Ferguson has received quite a bit of criticism for not signing a combative central midfielder in the summer, and justifiably so," writes David Wall. "But is there a more sympathetic interpretation in that perhaps, that he wanted to give a bit of encouragement to Darren Fletcher, that he would still have an important part to play for them if and when he was able to return to fitness? It's quite well established how highly Fergie thinks of Fletcher, especially with him being a fellow Scot, and with his developing to justify his place after a slow start when he received a lot of criticism from fans. Or is that being too charitable and Ferguson's wine has more likely blinded him to what's lacking in his midfield rather than make him mellow in his old age?"

21 min: Another goal chance for Manchester United, with Javier Hernandez grinning sheepishly and waving apologetically to his team-mates after scuffing wide at the far post when he should have done better.

23 min: "Bearing in mind the wave of near-constant mediocrity that Obertan has ridden over the last few years, exactly how well do you think he would have to play tonight to make Fergie regret shunting him out of Old Trafford?" asks Matt Dony.

To be honest, Matt, I think with over one quarter of this match having already elapsed and Mr Obertan having contributed nothing to the Newcastle cause thus far, I'm not sure there's enough time left for him to do all that would be required to make Fergie regret shunting him out of Old Trafford.

25 min: Another free-kick for Newcastle, halfway inside the Manchester United half, out on the left flank. Newcastle settle into their established routine of waiting for centre-backs Williamson and Coloccini to lumber up the pitch to try to get on the end of Sylvain Marveaux's long ball into the box. Their trip is wasted on this occasion, as the Frenchman sends the ball swirling into the arms of David De Gea.

27 min: Rooney shows his class, playing a marvellous 40-yard pass up the left touchline to Danny Welbeck. The No19 brings it under control, cuts inside and unleashes a low diagonal drive. Rob Elliot saves well.

29 min: Ooh, what's this ...

31 min: Gabriel Obertan does his best to make Alex Ferguson regret shunting him out of Old Trafford by picking up the ball on the right flank, looking up to see where his team-mates are and deftly playing a cross nowhere near any of them and straight into the arms of David De Gea.

34 min: That's a terrible, terrible, terrible, terrible, terrible, terrible, terrible, terrible miss from Tom Cleverley, who has yet to score a goal for Manchester United. It was the move of the match, with Hernandez playing a pass from the right-flank to Welbeck on the edge of the penalty area. He laid off for Rooney, who couldn't quite get to it. The ball broke for the following-up Hernandez and he put it on a plate for Cleverley, who shot wide of a gaping goal from 10 yards out with only Elliot to beat.

38 min: Newcastle win a corner, then another. Marveaux takes both, taking an eternity to jog from one quadrant to the other. Manchester United clear, with the camera cutting to Anderson, who chooses that exact moment to lift his shirt to check something on his waist. I say this from a position of weakness, but he's carrying a lot of excess baggage for a professional athlete - there's definite muffin-top flab discernible hanging over his shorts.

41 min: That last entry reminds of the time that Eamon Dunphy once got them to stop a piece of VT on Irteland's answer to Match of the Day, so he could use his electronic marker to draw a big ring around the clearly fat backside of John Hartson, then of Wimbledon, to demonstrate what was wrong with the team. "Look at the size of that, Bill!" he said, or words to that effect. "That's what's wrong with Wimbledon right there."

GOAL! Manchester United 1-0 Newcastle (Anderson 44): Em ... Anderson uses his considerable weight to hold off Dan Gosling as he moved from right to left across the outside of the penalty area, before unleashing a drive that left Rob Elliot with no chance. That's a fine strike.

Half-time: Manchester United go in at half-time a goal up courtesy of Anderson's first goal for nearly a year.

A trip down memory lane with Geoff Ashworth: "Re. the reference to the last time Newcastle won at OT being 1972," he says. "I was at that game. Correct me if I am wrong, but Newcastle had just been dumped out of the FA Cup by non-league Hereford the week before. I could tell they were up for the game at OT when, at kick off, they had the most determined, committed body language. I knew MUFC would have a bad day. I bet Newcastle had the early version of the hair drier treatment that week!"

As much as I would love to correct you if you are wrong, Geoff, I'm afraid I can't without consulting the record books. I was no more than a mischievous gleam in my father's eye in 1972 and wasn't born until the following year.

I can confirm that Newcastle's defeat at the hands of Hereford and their last win over Manchester United at Old Trafford were both in February 1972. I wouldn't be conceived for another four or five months.

An email from Simon McMahon: "This game needed an Alan Partridge moment," he writes. "Trust Anderson to deliver it. BOOF! Eat my goal! The goalkeeper (and MBM reporter) has football pie all over his face."

At the risk of sounding pedantic, I think you'll find the goalkeeper (and MBM reporter) has football pie all over his shirt. He must have a foot like a traction engine.

Second half is go. I don't think there have been any changes on either side, although I can't be certain because I was eating a Twix when the teams emerged for the second half. Unprofessional, I know, but I didn't remember it was in my pocket until near the end of half-time.

46 min: Danny Welbeck beats his man on the left and plays the ball across the edge of the penalty area to Anderson, who blasts the ball ridiculously high over the bar and then waves an apology at his provider.

48 min: Not for the first time tonight, Marnick Vermiji pings a beautiful cross in towards the near post from the right. Javier Hernandez tries to flick the ball in at the near post from close range, but can't get enough purchase on it and skims it wide.

49 min: Shola Ameobi tries a snap-shot from the edge of the Manchester United penalty area, but can only scuff the ball into the arms of David De Gea.

52 min: A promising looking Newcastle move ends with Sky co-commentator Alan Smith (the Arsenal old boy, not the Emmerdale Eminem) sighing "... but a waste at the end". The camera immediately cuts to Newcastle No25 Gabriel Obertan looking doleful.

55 min: Good play from Vuckic with his back to goal in the Manchester United penalty area. He picks up a straightforward pass from Coloccini, shimmies this way and that before turning his man and unleashing a shot that curls a foot the wrong side of the right post.

With his abject apology for reporting the truth to the nation about the Queen's remarks to the home secretary about Abu Hamza, George Entwistle has failed his first test as BBC director general (Report, 26 September). That means it must override the personal feelings of an octogenarian monarch who, like her eldest son, indulges in a non-constitutional relationship with elected politicians (Government fights release of royal veto rules, 26 September).

The BBC must now end its subservient and pro-monarchy role and adopt the neutral stance its charter requires in all its conduct. As for the royals, they must either stop making political remarks or resign their office and become a low-cost bicycling monarchy with a purely symbolic role and no power of patronage. They cannot have it both ways.

It would be hard to imagine a more thankless task at the present moment than defending the Right Honourable member for Sutton Coldfield, parliamentary secretary to the Treasury (as the chief whip is formally known). Andrew Mitchell looks remarkably friendless. He has been derided in these pages, but that derision is surpassed by the venomous hatred of the Daily Mail, which loathes the Cameron government in any case and particularly despised Mitchell in his previous job. As international development secretary, he was the man who gave rather modest sums of our money away to hungry dusky foreigners, something the Mail truly can't abide.

Come to think of it, I shan't seriously try to defend him. Mitchell made a fool of himself, and in a boorish fashion. Even the fact that many of us have lost our temper with aggressive police officers is not much of an excuse, though few would have used Mitchell's esoteric epithet (if he did). Quite whether "pleb" is a term of abuse is another question. Everyone seems to have forgotten the Plebs' League – the Marxist group, originally in the south Wales coalfields, that organised working-class education – and its Plebs' Magazine, hundred-year-old copies of which are collectors' items.

But hang on. If Mitchell is supposed to be the villain of the piece, who are the heroes? Why do we know about the altercation at all? Because one of the officers concerned did what any normal British bobby does, and told the Sun. No heroics there, I suggest. For years past the police have been leaking – and sometimes selling – confidential information to the tabloids, contrary to the administration of justice, or basic decency. This has happened to weak and obscure people, and has led to a cause celebre this time only because of Mitchell's prominence. If the officer was aggrieved he should have complained privately, and accepted what would rightly have been a grovelling apology.

Instead, everyone has acted in character. David Cameron has briefed against his own chief whip, and may yet illustrate Jeremy Thorpe's quip about Harold Macmillan, an earlier Etonian premier: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his friends for his life." Cameron forgets (as did Margaret Thatcher) that a prime minister who shows no loyalty to colleagues may not get much in return when it matters, and he forgets also that when the howling pack has tasted blood, it wants more. It could be his turn next. As to the demagogic meddling of the mayor of London – who thinks it would have been "wholly commonsensical" to arrest Mitchell – it's if nothing else a useful reminder that Boris Johnson is never knowingly outshitted. If the Tories really want a cynical unprincipled opportunist as leader, at least they know where to look.

We are told that it was the worst possible moment for a minister to insult the police, just after the deaths of two brave policewomen in Manchester. But it was also just after the real story finally emerged at last about Hillsborough. On that appalling occasion, gross police incompetence aggravated the tragedy, and the police then behaved in an utterly despicably manner by blaming the victims for heir own deaths. This was done – need one add? – with the connivance of the Sun, a headline on whose front page reading THE TRUTH is in any circumstances beyond satire.

If Mitchell may seem a little rebarbative to some tastes, he would have to try hard to be more obnoxious than John Tully, who has demanded his resignation. Tully is chair of the Metropolitan Police Federation, and thus represents that fine body who maintain law and order in our capital with such courtesy, efficiency and restraint. Just ask Jean Charles de Menezes or Ian Tomlinson.

Actually, you can't ask them since they're dead, at the hands of the Met, whose policy nowadays is often "Shoot first, ask questions later" – or better still, no questions asked at all.

Few worse things have happened in my lifetime than the deterioration of our police. We have lost the priceless legacy of Sir Robert Peel. Almost uniquely in Europe he gave us not a gun-toting paramilitary gendarmerie but "citizens in uniform", an unarmed police force under civilian control. Now we have heavily armed police who often appear to be under no one's control. Politicians bear a heavy responsibility for this, notably Thatcher, who assaulted unions and vested interests with the conspicuous exception of the police: she needed their support in sundry industrial conflicts.

And of course she also worked hand in glove with Rupert Murdoch, before whom Tony Blair and Cameron have since knelt in fealty. Wednesday saw the appearance of Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson at the Old Bailey. That case continues, as does the investigation into allegations of the corrupt interpenetration of News International and the Metropolitan police. On the whole, it might seem like quite a good if the police kept their distance from the Murdoch tabloids for a while.

As to Mitchell, part of his family fortune comes from El Vino, the Fleet Street wine bar where we drank in happier days. When his father, Sir David Mitchell, was in parliament, Private Eye used to call him "the barman MP, as he likes to be known" (he didn't). Loutish Tory MPs once heckled the former ship's steward John Prescott with shouts of "Large gin and tonic". If, as I hope, Mitchell survives the baying mob, Labour MPs could greet him with "A bottle of Bollinger and three glasses". That, and a copy of the Plebs' Magazine for Christmas.

It is shortly after five on a Sunday afternoon. Outside the streets are rain-slicked and autumnal; leaves cling to paving stones, and the sky is a dispiriting shade of lead. High up in the 6Music building in central London, the mood is somewhat warmer. Over the control panels and the coffee machine, the sofas and the swivel chairs, spills a disembodied voice: rich and dry and northern, riffing on wedding singers and listener requests, 70s funk rarities and Bruce Springsteen's Nebraska.

If you squint through the glass and into the dimly lit studio, you can vaguely make out the shape of Jarvis Cocker, with his producer, Adam Dineen, beside him. Together they are steering the show towards six o'clock, segueing gently from Gustav Holst's Neptune into Scout Niblett's 2005 track Kidnapped by Neptune.

Cocker's Sunday Service show has been a fixture on 6Music for more than two and a half years now, and remains one of the station's most popular programmes – an essential part of a Sunday schedule notable for the number of shows hosted by musicians, from Cerys Matthews in the morning, via Huey Morgan, Cocker and, later, Guy Garvey of Elbow. Cocker's show is a great stew of conversation, spoken word and musical exploration. In his first year, Cocker won a Sony Radio "rising star" award. Last year, he was nominated for Sony's radio personality award, losing out to Ronnie Wood.

Cocker and Dineen emerge shortly after their final song (The Velvet Underground's I'm Sticking With You, requested by Bernie from Dorset), Cocker in tweed jacket and black cords, clutching an armful of vinyl and a small, blue-lidded record box. The pair began working together on Valentine's Day 2010, and Cocker says he remembers it well. "Adam came in on that show and I was impressed because my researching is always a bit last-minute, like everything in my life is a bit last-minute," he recalls. "We were getting ready for Michael Palin to come on to be interviewed, and I was doing my extensive research, which is always just looking at people's Wikipedia pages, and I saw that Palin had been involved in writing some lyrics for a record by a guy called Barry Booth in the 60s…"

Cocker thought that it would be a very good thing to play this Barry Booth record on that Sunday's show. Unfortunately, it was Friday, and the last day for ordering records from the BBC record library in Perivale was Thursday. "So I thought, 'I've messed up there,'" Cocker says flatly. "But then I found that Adam had already ordered it. So I thought, hmmm, there's somebody who's more organised than I am, and that's what I need."

Each show begins to take shape on the Monday or Tuesday before broadcast. "It will start with me looking through the things that have happened on that day," Cocker explains. "The show isn't totally based around that – sometimes it's things that have actually happened in the previous week. But that gives it a structure, and for me that's useful because often an event will suggest a song for us to play."

He is quite fastidious about this part of the process. "I get my notebook out and write down events and births and …" He allows a faint smile to cross his face. "At first we did have deaths, too, but death is just a downer, there's no getting round it." Cocker fishes a small, violet-coloured notebook from the inside pocket of his jacket and opens it at a random page full of tight, scrawly handwriting. "So I'll have a look down my notes, and find something like the Mayflower set off for the US on 16 September 1620. And so that made me think of that Wooden Ships song by Crosby Stills & Nash. It's helpful to me, and makes me feel that all that random knowledge littered about is in some way useful."

He is drawn, he says, to songs that are particularly innovative with language. "And that's why there's quite a lot of spoken-word stuff on the show," he says. "I think that gets overlooked a lot. And that's certainly what I'll latch on to as what I like in a song. I appreciate people who try and use language in an interesting way." On other occasions, his research will lead the show into entirely new territory. He calls to mind a recent example: the American musician Korla Pandit. "I'd never heard of him, but he was born on 16 September 1921. I just thought it was an interesting name, so I looked him up and he was a very interesting guy who made out he was some Indian mystic type of figure and played the organ. So I asked Adam to look into it and we dug out some tracks by him."

Part of Dineen's job is to wrangle with the troublesome library search engine. "It's hard to use," he says, "but at the end you get all these offshoots of what you were researching — like, with the anniversary of the Penny Black stamp, I found a strange seven inch on a label I'd never heard of, a guy singing a strange disco track called Penny Black. And then his son heard it, and he wrote us a letter saying thank you very much." The letter, Cocker adds, "had loads of stamps on the front".

Cocker first arrived at the station as a stand-in for Stephen Merchant. "And I suppose they thought I did a reasonable job," he says. "I'd always fought against presenting radio really, because my father was a radio DJ in Australia. He's just recently retired. And I kind of didn't want to follow in his footsteps. But I suppose, as we all find as we become older, to some extent we do all become our parents." His father did offer him one very useful broadcasting tip. "He said, 'Turn the headphones up as loud as you possibly can, because then you won't shout at the microphone. You'll just speak to it in a normal way, and that draws the listener in.' And you know what? It's true. Except it's sending me deaf."

Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the video.

Radio presenting has some similarities with his other job, as a solo artist and frontman of Pulp. "It's like a performance," he says. "Not that you would have guessed it, looking through the glass – there's not a lot of action going on. It's just people in chairs. But there is a performative aspect to it. We try to pick the songs that go well together, we put them in groups of two so they kind of bounce off each other. And similarly, with a concert, you're trying to communicate with the audience, and that's why as much as possible, we try and do the show live, because you can get people involved. Like today, we asked for wedding song suggestions, so they can communicate with you and we can together decide on the last song. And that's nice, you know?"

Sunday afternoon brings a particularly intimate and informal audience. Many listeners text or tweet to say they are busy making their Sunday dinner, and on a rainy day like today, they email in droves. "That's another part of the concept, I suppose, that it's pretty laid-back," says Cocker. "When I was more of a drinker, I always found that hangovers got to their worst around 4pm. You're over the physical thing, and it goes into a psychological thing by then. So I thought it would be good to do a show that helps you through that difficult time — without being bland, but being quite soothing." He smiles, a slight pursing of the lips. "To me, it's what Sundays used to be like. At one time we used to say we were bringing the boredom back to Sunday, and that might be overstating it, but it's that kind of thing. That the week's kind of finished, but the new week hasn't begun, so you've got this weird kind of floaty time where you can be a bit more reflective. It's not a massive concept," he adds, with typical self-effacement.

This weekend, Cocker will present his show from A Room for London, a small boat stationed atop the Queen Elizabeth Hall next to the Thames in London. "Because we're near water, we're going to try and have a little bit of an aquatic theme, looking for writings about the Thames," he says. "We'll have a guy called Philip Sheppard, who plays the electric cello, and did a record called The Diver in the Crypt. We'll do some semi-improvised thing of him playing and me intoning some texts."

They have no real plans for any more wild specials, though they mention an upcoming interview with Art Garfunkel, perhaps more events such as Cocker's Q&A with Leonard Cohen this February, and a hoped-for show from the French national radio record archives (this would be similar to one they recorded at the music library in Perivale, delving into the collection's oddities). "At one point, we thought about doing a visual version," Cocker says. "Because the format would work for TV – you could look at things that had happened, show little clips and things, and I'd sort of be quite interested in doing that." He gives the faintest flutter of a smile. "Or perhaps we could write a musical. Perhaps we should do the show on ice …"

If just one thing can be guaranteed at this weekend's Ryder Cup, it is that both captains will be put through the mill. In 1953, for example, the US captain Lloyd Mangrum estimated that he suffered "nine thousand deaths in the last hour" alone. But even though nerve-pulverising intensity is an absolute certainty, José María Olazábal is primarily worried about his opening ceremony speech. "That's the part I feel uncomfortable with," he says. "It's tough. We are used to hitting tee shots, chips and putts, but that is so different."

Olazábal would be wise to keep it short and simple, and double-check all his facts. No Ryder Cup has ever been won as a result of a rousing opening address, but one or two might have been lost. Corey Pavin set the tone for the USA's defeat in 2010 by forgetting to introduce Stewart Cink a slapdash attitude to detail, which later manifested itself in the team's waterproofs (which weren't waterproof).

In 2004, the freewheelin' Hal Sutton went one better, forgetting how many children he had. Having thanked his fourth wife Ashley for providing him with three kids, Halimony was forced to quickly backtrack as Mrs Sutton held up four fingers as a prompt. That she didn't configure those fingers in two groups of two is to her credit. Sutton, clearly not at the races, spent the rest of the week gadding about in an outsized cowboy hat, and pairing Tiger Woods with Phil Mickelson. The US were thrashed.

But perhaps Nick Faldo's efforts in 2008 did the most to give the opposing team a boost. He referred to Soren Hansen as Soren Stenson, suggested Padraig Harrington had hit more practice shots than there are potatoes in Ireland, and told Graeme McDowell it made little difference whether he came from Northern Ireland or the Republic. A very strange sandwich analogy - "Cheese next to your name? You'll play all five matches. Tuna means four matches, chicken is three, lettuce is two" - also fell flat. "Nick fancies himself as a comedian and he's not funny," opined US coach Butch Harmon after the event, which the Americans won easily. Still, stopped clocks and all that. "See you in Wales," began Faldo's valedictory quip at the closing ceremony, "and bring your waterproofs with you." Corey Pavin might wish he'd paid closer attention.

Imagine the British landscape with a third fewer trees. That is the chilling prediction being made this week by the Woodland Trust.

A fungus that has already affected 90% of ash trees in Denmark over the past seven years has now been detected in a handful of locations in the UK. If our government does not act urgently, warns the Woodland Trust, all Britain's estimated 80m ash trees could be lost to the fungal disease known as "ash dieback".

There is no effective remedy apart from felling and burning affected trees and banning imports of live ash saplings from mainland Europe, where the fungus has taken hold. Some arborists fear such actions might already be too late.

As a child, growing up in Cornwall when Dutch elm disease was sweeping the UK, I remember staring up in awe at a row of majestic elms on the daily drive to school. Then, suddenly, they were gone. By the 90s, the disease had claimed more than 25m elms across the UK. But ash dieback could have an even more devastating impact.

Alongside oak and birch, ash is one of the most common native broadleaf trees and accounts for roughly 30% of our "wooded landscape", which includes parks and hedgerows, as well as woods and forests. It is relatively fast growing, prized as firewood and charcoal, and its strength and elasticity means it has a variety of uses – gates, tool handles, oars and furniture.

"The loss of ash on this scale would be an environmental disaster," says Norman Starks, the Woodland Trust's operations director. "The impact on woodland biodiversity would be huge. We can delay it by using the English Channel as a barrier and banning imports of live saplings. But there is a danger that we will just shrug our shoulders and then have to explain to future generations why we failed to act."

Dr John Morgan, head of the Forestry Commission's Plant Health Service, agrees that the fungus poses a serious threat, but says there is not enough evidence yet to suggest all ash trees will be lost should the fungus take hold. "We still don't know for sure how it will respond to conditions in Britain, but I'd be surprised if we lost more than 90% of our ash. However, the only reliable control is banning imports."

The financial cost of losing all of our ash is incalculable, but it would also damage our cultural heritage. The origin of the word "ash" is often attributed to the Anglo-Saxon term for spear, a common use of the tree in past centuries. Odin, the feared Viking god, hanged himself on an ash tree – known as the "world tree", or Yggdrasil – as a sacrificial ordeal. And many previous generations have celebrated the ash's "healing" properties.

In 1940, when John Goddard was 15, he made a list of everything he wanted to achieve. There were 127 goals in all, which included: visit every country in the world; explore the Great Barrier Reef; watch a cremation ceremony in Bali; milk a poisonous snake; and visit the Moon. Some goals were bundled together. Number 113, for example, reads: "Become proficient in the use of a plane, motorcycle, tractor, surfboard, rifle, pistol, canoe, microscope, football, basketball, bow and arrow, lariat and boomerang." There is a tick beside this one, marking it as done, as there is beside 109 of those original goals. And in the years since, he has set himself hundreds more, writing them down as a form of commitment.

Goddard's "Life List", which featured in the Chicken Soup for the Soul self-help franchise, is one of the inspirations cited by people who have created what are now more usually called bucket lists. The phrase derives from "kick the bucket", a term for death, with unclear origins, but which quite likely relates to the bucket kicked away at a hanging. It was popularised by the 2007 film The Bucket List, in which characters played by Jack Nicholson and Morgan Freeman meet in a cancer ward, then race around the world, packing in experiences. As in that story, some people start these lists when diagnosed with incurable illnesses, and in those cases the goals often seem to have a deeper, much more personal flavour. On Tuesday, for instance, it was reported that former PR executive Simon Mitchell, who has a cancer of the blood, has been pursuing a list that involves helping other people, using his professional contacts to set up meetings between seriously ill children and the stars they admire.

But the trend goes much wider. Bill Clinton, Jane Fonda and Cameron Diaz have spoken of having a list. Last week, a man who had camped overnight for an iPhone 5 said that specific experience was included on his. And it was also reported that Megan Stammers, the 15-year-old girl thought to be in France with her maths teacher, had posted her own extensive list online. The last entry, fall in love, had been crossed off.

There are no end of websites for those wanting to compile and share their ambitions, with a whole industry having formed around the notion of cramming in eye-popping, hedonic experiences before you die: sky-diving, mountain climbing, throwing tomatoes at the Tomatina festival in Spain and meeting pop stars. On bucketlist.org someone proclaims their ambition to hold a baby white tiger; on bucketlist.net there are plans to fly in a hot-air balloon. A series of books lists the 1,001 films you should see, the 1,001 albums you should listen to, all the paintings and natural wonders you must catch, in order to be fulfilled before death. And while this approach can sound quite the opposite of fulfilment, an endless striving for satisfaction, that hasn't stopped people's wild enthusiasm.

Are bucket lists really a good idea? It can be useful to have defined goals, of course, but the lists seem to encourage a strange blend of highly individualised behaviour and conformity, a situation in which everyone is hurtling, alone, towards similar goals. The psychotherapist Philippa Perry suggests, laughingly, that they might actually have been started "as a brilliant PR stunt by somebody who was selling swimming with dolphins". There's a consumerist, acquisitive vibe to many of the lists, with the experience they replicate being the writing of a shopping list, says Perry. Instead of building on what you already have, "to make a good life," she continues, "it's really an attempt to fill an existential void".

There's also an innate air of competition to bucket lists, of striving to best yourself – but also others. In some ways it's no surprise that they have risen in popularity in an age when we are all encouraged to brand ourselves, to treat our Facebook pages as a shop window for our achievement-rich lives. Psychologist Linda Blair, who is writing a book called The Key to Calm, to help people deal with stress and anxiety, says chasing big experiences is worthwhile if you enjoy the whole process. "Saving up the money, planning it with friends, and then the moment as well. I'm all for that," she says. "But if you're constantly living in the future, ignoring what's going on right now because you're shooting for goals, which happen so quickly that they're over, and then you have to chase another one, you're not really living."

Could they be a useful way of dealing with the inevitability of death? Blair doesn't think so. "It's a way of denying the idea of death, not coping with it at all ... People usually do this to ensure that there are things to look forward to, which means there are things that are still going to happen … My experience warns me that it's probably done in order to prevent thinking about death." Perry sees it as a way of dealing "with how to pass the time. I think it's a way of trying to generate some excitement.

"What we should be doing in our bucket lists," Perry says, "is learning how to be open with our own vulnerabilities so that we can form connections with other human beings … I think, for me, what's wrong with the bucket list is that it's individualistic – the idea of the isolated self goes very deep in Western society – and I think it's a red herring ... It's a distraction from the business of being human. We don't all like swimming with dolphins but we are all made to connect to each other. That's the really fun thing to do before you die."
